posts.name: Milan Lustig
posts.cooked:
Hello Everyone!

I’m one of the code captains from team 2875, and we are very excited to announce the full release of our team’s open-source swerve-drive focused library, SwoLib ! Contrasting with most swerve libraries, SwoLib does NOT wrap WPILib SwerveDriveKinematics , or any other WPILib swerve-related classes. Instead, SwoLib’s swerve utilities are based on custom-built kinematics, odometry, autonomous, pathplanning software, and math classes.

SwoLib, however, is not just a swerve drive library. SwoLib contains utilities and wrapper classes for various pieces of hardware, including (but not limited to!) Limelights, motors & controllers (Falcon500, NEO, etc), gyros (Pigeon, NavX), encoders, and much more. SwoLib is also Kotlin based, allowing teams who program in Kotlin to take advantage of the language’s various higher-level features, but also boasting full compatibility with Java.

As for the swerve drive related parts of the library, SwoLib includes built-in odometry to track the position of the robot on the field in 2 or 3d space. This odometry can also (optionally) be integrated with SwoLib’s limelight to automatically correct for any drift with 2023’s AprilTags.

Arguably the most distinct aspect of SwoLib is its fully dynamic autonomous capabilities. Thanks to the aforementioned AprilTag-based positioning, a robot employing SwoLib’s autonomous utilities is capable of starting anywhere on the field and following the same predefined paths. SwoLib performs motion-profiling and path calculations at runtime. The paths are composed of a list of waypoints which can be generated from our own modified version of pathplanner (open source and linked in the SwoLib repository). This allows the robot to discern its position on the field using a Limelight + AprilTags and then move to the correct starting position when the autonomous period begins! Not only can this be applied in autonomous, but also in the teleop period too! Team 2875 uses this to automatically position our robot to place cones/cubes (in teleop), and we are capable of beginning this automatic positioning from anywhere on the field!

For more information, please check out the GitHub repository (linked above) example projects (found in the repository) and the extensive SwoLib documentation . Please feel free to reach out with any questions!

PS - Apologies for making you search for links. As a new account, Chief Delphi limited me to two links in this post.

link_counts.title: GitHub - CshCyberhawks/SwoLib: The 2875 Cyberhawks utility library for FRC (Kotlin/Java)

posts.name: Ryan Smith
posts.cooked: We welcome any feedback you may have. If you find any bugs or have suggestions for new features, please don’t hesitate to create an issue. Our team is committed to addressing and resolving any issues as promptly as possible.

This looks really nice!

Why did you use custom odometry when WPILib odometry now uses encoder inputs for odometry now too?

Is there a reason you avoided using the PID from the motor controllers themselves?

I do like how you’re doing most math in polar coordinates.

You may want to consider a way to disable telemetry if a team desires that bc this could clutter a driver station very easily.

You may want to decouple limelight’s and go for generic vision pose resetting because vision estimation can still be imprecise and may need filtered out more than you could expect (see Advantage Kit for the perfect example).

You could also use a generic interface for motors instead of separating drive motors and turning motors, like this .

I would also recommend against using a custom PathPlanner, not because what you have done is bad, but because it involves more work supporting every release of it (which means you will almost always be behind) and that is alot of unnecessary work. Instead i would recommend working with the creator to try to get your changes into a PR.

Your commands look really nice too!

posts.name: Milan Lustig
posts.cooked:
Thank you!

We don’t use the PIDs from the motor controllers to ensure maximum compatibility, as not all motor controllers have them. Last year, our team used NEOs with CANSparkMaxes and 775 motors controlled from VictorSPXs, so we decided to make sure SwoLib is usable with any type of motor/controller. In the future we may add the option for teams who wish to use built in PIDs.

I didn’t even realize the telemetry wasn’t optional! Thank you for pointing that out, I will fix that.

As for the generic vision pose estimating, I like that idea! In the future, we will add that.

I’m not sure why we use separate interfaces for driving and turning motors; I believe the reason for that got lost in some refactor. I will make sure we update that to a single interface.

As for the PathPlanner, our customizations are solely in the output JSON (pretty much an added toJSON function) to output solely the waypoints without the excess data. In the future, we may switch to a simple script to parse the default pathplanner JSON into our form. We didn’t want to parse it at runtime to maintain as much performance as possible.

Again, thank you so much for these suggestions. Our code team is mentor-less (all students), so you have been incredibly helpful!
You are doing amazing work without one so far and you should be proud of yourselves!

posts.name: Milan Lustig
posts.cooked:
Thank you!

I also just realized that you are the creator of YAGSL and want to say that it looks awesome!
